definition[0]: measuring a long distance from the bottom to the top
example[0]: This is the highest mountain in Japan.
example[1]: The camp was surrounded by a high fence.
example[2]: How high is the Eiffel Tower?
definition[1]: in a position that is a long way, or a longer way than usual, above the ground, floor etc
example[6]: The apartment had spacious rooms with high ceilings.
example[9]: The sun was already high in the sky.
example[10]: High up among the clouds, we saw the summit of Everest.
definition[2]: a high amount, number, or level is large, or larger than usual
example[11]: Temperatures remained high for the rest of the week.
example[12]: Lower-paid workers often cannot afford the high cost of living in the capital.
example[13]: The train was approaching at high speed.
example[14]: High levels of car use mean our streets are more congested than ever.
example[17]: If you want better public services, you’ll have to pay higher taxes – it’s as simple as that.
example[18]: A high proportion of women with children under five work full-time.
definition[3]: a high standard, quality etc is very good
example[20]: Our aim is to provide the highest quality service to all our customers.
example[21]: a range of high-quality goods at low prices
example[22]: The general standard of the entries was very high.
example[23]: Our guests expect us to maintain high standards.
definition[4]: containing a lot of a particular substance or quality
example[24]: Choose foods that are high in fiber and low in calories.
example[25]: Red meat tends to have a high fat content.
definition[5]: having an important position in society or within an organization
note[9]: high society (=rich people of the highest social class)
example[26]: a high rank in the US Navy
example[28]: someone high up in the CIA
example[29]: Both of them held high office in the Anglican Church.
note[12]: the higher animals/mammals/organisms etc (=animals etc that are more intelligent or advanced than others)
example[30]: We can offer all the benefits of the latest high technology.
definition[7]: near or above the top of the range of sounds that humans can hear
example[32]: I always had difficulty reaching the high notes  (=when singing).
example[34]: I was still high from the applause.
definition[9]: behaving in a strange and excited way as the result of taking drugs
note[13]: get high (=take a drug to make yourself high)
example[35]: Steve was as high as a kite (=strongly affected by drugs or alcohol).
example[36]: Most people there were high on cocaine.
definition[10]: having risen to a high level
example[37]: The river is at its highest in spring.
definition[11]: the middle or the most important part of a particular period of time
note[15]: high noon (=12 o'clock in the middle of the day)
definition[12]: cheese, meat etc that is high is not fresh and has a strong smell or taste
definition[13]: a very formal style of language, especially used in literature
definition[14]: a form of a language used for formal purposes that is often different from the ordinary form used by most people
definition[15]: measuring a long distance from the bottom to the top – used about mountains, walls, and buildings
example[39]: the highest mountain in the world
example[40]: The castle was surrounded by high walls.
example[42]: The council told the architects the tower was too high.
definition[16]: high – used about people, trees, plants, and buildings. Tall is used especially about things that are high and narrow
example[44]: A cat was hiding in the tall grass.
definition[17]: very impressive because of being very big and tall – used about mountains, buildings, trees, and animals
example[46]: the majestic mountains of the Himalayas
example[47]: The abbey is noted for its majestic arches, fine doorways and elegant windows.
example[48]: The cathedral looked majestic in the evening light.
definition[18]: used about a building or mountain that looks extremely tall and impressive
example[50]: the soaring towers of the palace
definition[19]: extremely high, in a way that seems impressive but also often rather frightening
example[51]: The sky was shut out by the towering walls of the prison.
definition[20]: very high and impressive – used in literature
example[53]: the lofty peaks in the far distance
definition[21]: a high-rise building is a tall modern building with a lot of floors containing apartments or offices
example[55]: He works in a high-rise office in New York.
definition[22]: higher than most sounds or voices
example[56]: He has a rather high-pitched voice.
example[58]: the high-pitched whine of a dentist's drill
example[60]: The bird has rather a shrill cry.
definition[24]: extremely high and loud, in a way that is unpleasant
example[62]: Suddenly I heard a piercing whistle.
definition[25]: making very high noises that are not loud
definition[26]: at or to a level high above the ground, the floor etc
example[66]: He kicked the ball high into the air, over the heads of the crowd.
example[67]: Hotel Miramar is situated high above the bay.
example[68]: A ski lift whisks you high into the mountains.
definition[27]: at or to a high value, cost, amount etc
example[69]: If prices shoot up any higher, no one will be able to afford to live in the area.
example[70]: Tom scored higher than anyone else in the class.
example[71]: A strange cry rang high into the night.
definition[29]: at or to a high rank or level of achievement, especially within a company
example[72]: It seems that the higher you rise, the less time you have to actually do your job.
example[73]: My parents always encouraged me to aim high.
definition[30]: the highest price, number, temperature etc that has ever been recorded, or that has been recorded within a particular period of time
example[74]: Highs of 40°C were recorded in the region last summer.
example[75]: The price of oil reached a new high this week.
definition[31]: a feeling of great happiness or excitement
example[76]: They’re bound to be on a high after such an incredible victory.
example[77]: the emotional highs and lows of a new romance
definition[32]: a feeling of pleasure or excitement produced by some drugs
definition[33]: an area of high pressure that affects the weather
definition[34]: a short form of high school, used in the name of a school
example[79]: The wall was about chest-high  (=as high as your chest).
definition[36]: the largest amount, figure, value etc in a particular period of time
example[81]: Advancing stocks again led as 162 issues reached new highs and only 14 dropped to new lows.
definition[37]: a high amount, number, or level is more than normal, more than average, or more than it was before
example[83]: A high proportion of female directors are in the 35-to-55 age range.
example[84]: Sales to rental car companies made up a high percentage of the vehicles sold by General Motors.
example[85]: There is still a high risk that the US currency will fall back during the year.
definition[38]: a high position in an organization is an important one
example[86]: He rose swiftly to high office.
definition[39]: at or to a high amount, number, level etc
example[87]: Prices could go even higher early this year.
example[88]: Western-educated technocrats high up in powerful bureaucracies
